conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas at state B, we need to analyze the processes involved and use the ideal gas law and the given information.
State A has a pressure \( p_A = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and volume \( V_A = 2 \, \text{L} \). The temperature at state A is \( T_A = 200 \, \text{K} \).

The process A → B appears to be an isobaric process (constant pressure) because the pressure remains constant from A to B. The volume changes from \( V_A = 2 \, \text{L} \) to \( V_B = 5 \, \text{L} \).

premise: Use the ideal gas law for the isobaric process A → B: \n\[ \frac{V_A}{T_A} = \frac{V_B}{T_B} \] Substituting the known values: \n\[ \frac{2 \, \text{L}}{200 \, \text{K}} = \frac{5 \, \text{L}}{T_B} \]
According to the ideal gas equation of state \(\frac{P_{A}V_{A}}{T_{A}}=\frac{P_{B}V_{B}}{T_{B}}\)
conclusion: The temperature of the gas at state B is 800K.
